abstract: United Technologies is in good enough shape to buy assets, while General Electric has been paying for a bet that did not pay off.
snippet: United Technologies is in good enough shape to buy assets, while General Electric has been paying for a bet that did not pay off.
lead_paragraph: It is only fitting that United Technologies is poised to buy assets from its cross-state rival General Electric. At least in the eyes of shareholders, United Technologies  the manufacturer of Otis elevators, Pratt & Whitney jet engines and Sikorsky helicopters  has emerged as the more successful of the two industrial conglomerates, both based in Connecticut.

headline.main: As G.E. Struggles, a Rival Steps Up
headline.print_headline: As G.E. Struggles, a Rival Steps Up

byline.original: By Rob Cox and Robert Cyran

abstract: United Technologies is in position to swoop in and buy businesses from General Electric, whose big bet on finance is forcing it to shrink and its shareholders to suffer, Breakingviews says.
snippet: United Technologies is in position to swoop in and buy businesses from General Electric, whose big bet on finance is forcing it to shrink and its shareholders to suffer, Breakingviews says.
lead_paragraph: It is only fitting that United Technologies is poised to buy assets from its cross-state rival General Electric, Breakingviews says. At least in the eyes of shareholders, United Technologies — the manufacturer of Otis elevators, Pratt & Whitney jet engines and Sikorsky helicopters — has emerged as the more successful of the two industrial conglomerates, both based in Connecticut, according to the publication.

headline.main: As G.E. Struggles, a Rival Steps Up

abstract: General Electric said on Thursday that it will sell its fire alarm and security systems unit to United Technologies for $1.82 billion, continuing a sale of what the industrial conglomerate considers noncore businesses.
snippet: General Electric said on Thursday that it will sell its fire alarm and security systems unit to United Technologies for $1.82 billion, continuing a sale of what the industrial conglomerate considers noncore businesses.
lead_paragraph: General Electric said on Thursday that it will sell its fire alarm and security systems unit to United Technologies for $1.82 billion, continuing a sale of what the industrial conglomerate considers noncore businesses.

headline.main: G.E. Sells Security Unit for $1.8 Billion

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: Recent announcements by GE Capital and Tennenbaum Capital Partners about their debtor-in-possession lending achievements show that the market for bankruptcy financing is alive and well.
snippet: Recent announcements by GE Capital and Tennenbaum Capital Partners about their debtor-in-possession lending achievements show that the market for bankruptcy financing is alive and well.
lead_paragraph: When Lyondell Chemical filed for bankruptcy in January, the restructuring world was abuzz that the company received debtor-in-possession financing at all.

headline.main: After Slow Start, DIP Lending Is in Full Swing

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: The deal, valued at $1.82 billion, will help General Electric to part with what it considers noncore businesses.
snippet: The deal, valued at $1.82 billion, will help General Electric to part with what it considers noncore businesses.
lead_paragraph: General Electric said Thursday that it would sell its fire alarm and security systems unit to United Technologies for $1.82 billion, continuing a sale of what the industrial conglomerate considers noncore businesses.

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced
